Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Structure, Dynamics, and Function of the Packaging RNA Studied using Site-directed Spin Labeling

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration: Nucleic acids are essential in biological processes, and information on nucleic acids structure and conformational changes is critical in understanding their functions. This project will establish a new method for investigating nucleic acids conformations. The method is based on the site-directed spin labeling (SDSL) technique, where structural and dynamic information is derived from a stable nitroxide radical attached at a specific site of a macro-molecule. The research will explore a nitroxide probe that can be attached, in an efficient and cost-effective manner, to arbitrary nucleic acid sequences. Nanometer distances between a pair of such nitroxides will be measured, and the resulting data will be utilized to map the global structures of nucleic acids. To demonstrate the SDSL methods, global structures of nucleic acid molecules without prior known high-resolution structures will be studied. These include the packaging RNA that plays an essential role in the strongest bio-molecular motor known today : the phi29 DNA packaging motor. The studies will set a precedent for a wide range of SDSL studies on nucleic acids and nucleic acid/protein complexes without prior high-resolution structures. Broader Impacts: The PI will establish innovative, inter-disciplinary programs that integrate research and teaching at both the undergraduate and graduate level. A new general education course, called "Genes, Life, and Society", will be developed. The course will present the nature of genes with rigorous and precise molecular descriptions of nucleic acids structure and function, and will link the scientific concepts with contemporary societal issues such as evolution and diversity of our society. The course will utilize "BioSIGHT", a multi-media teaching platform being developed at an NSF-funded center at USC. The class will target a large population of science and non-science students, and will be used in outreach programs to high-school teachers through public lectures and web sites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Work supported by this grant has led to the development of a family of nitroxide probes, called the R5-series, which can be efficiently attached at defined location(s) within arbitrary nucleic acid (i.e., DNA and RNA) sequences. Based on the R5-series, a generalizable tool-kit for mapping structures of RNA and DNA has been developed. This unique tool-kit has been applied to map the global structure (i.e., the overall shape) of a three-way junction in an RNA molecule that is critical for the function of the strongest biological motor. The data show that in solution this RNA three-way junction adopts a different conformation as compared to that observed in a crystal structure. These results suggest intrinsic variations in this RNA junction conformation, which may contribute to the function of this RNA as a communicator that bridges different protein components during motor function. Furthermore, the R5-series of probes have been shown to be capable of probing local environment in DNA duplexes at the level of individual nucleotide units, and may eventually allow a quantitative description of the sequence-dependent properties of large biologically relevant DNA molecules. Overall, outcomes of the research expand our ability to study complex RNA and DNA molecules, and yield understanding on RNA and DNA structure and dynamics that is difficult to obtain by other techniques.

 

Broader Impacts: Work supported by this grant has advanced methodology, enhanced research infrastructure and resource, and provided knowledge that benefits the broader scientific community. The R5-series not only allow studies of RNA and DNA using Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) spectroscopy, but also enable applications in other areas, such as Dynamic Nuclear Polarization and Paramagnetic Relaxation Enhancement studies of nucleic acids and protein/nucleic-acid complexes. Furthermore, a state-of-the-art pulsed EPR spectrometer has been acquired, which lay the foundation for a center for advanced EPR spectroscopic study of nucleic acids and protein/nucleic acid complexes, with users from regional institutions including Primarily Undergraduate Institutions (PUI). The work has contributed to student training at all levels, with emphasis on using a multidisciplinary approach and on promoting research participations of members from under-represented groups (e.g. local PUI minority undergraduates). Examples from the PI’s research are incorporated into classes and education programs to propel the growth of the Chemistry Department and the University.
